Name: wu jia pi
nan wu jia pi (southern wu jia pi)

Medical Function: aids in development of walking in toddlers
Contraindications:
Herb gatherers in the northern part of China usually use gang liu pi (xiang jia pi) (Asclepiadaceae) as “northern wu jia pi.” Most herb stores use northern wu jia pi in making wu jia pi wine.According to research of Zhao Zi Huang, long term use of wu jia pi wine causes death. Toxic reactions of wu jia pi wine made from northern wu jia pi include blindness, numbness in limbs, dizziness, and headache.
Use caution in patients with yinxu (yin deficient) and excessive heat.
Research: northern wu jia pi is a heart stimulant which is toxic for the heart.
Chemical Ingredients: vitamins A and B (维生素 甲，乙)

Root bark: obtained six compounds (diterpenoids, etc.): wu jia acid (五加酸, I); kaurenoic acid (異貝殼杉烯酸, II); l-sesamin (l-芝麻素, III); stigmasterol (豆甾醇, IV); β-sitosterol (β-谷甾醇, V); eleutheroside B (刺五加苷B, VI)

Name: e zui hua (鱷嘴花)
Other name: Siam snake grass 暹羅蛇草
qing jian 青箭《廣西藥植名錄》
zhu jie huang 竹節黃《中草藥植物》
rou zhi jie gu cao 柔枝節骨草

Geography: Yunnan; Guangxi; Guangdong; Hainan provinces of China
Maladies Treated: Strains and sprains of injuries (whole plant)
Diarrhea (Indonesia folk use: fresh herb preparation)
Medical Function: Anti-inflammatory effect: inhibition of neutrophil responsiveness [2] [7]
Against antiproliferative affect on cultured cancer cells [8]
Dosage: Whole dry herb 15–30 g, decoction, take orally. External application: use fresh whole herb, smash and apply on affected area.
Samples of Formulae:
Hepatitis with jaundice, or acites caused by hepatitis: dry herb 30 g. Add water, make into decoction and take orally. If fresh herb is used, use about 120 g, add drinking water, smash to make juice, take orally.

Hepatitis with jaundice: Xi shu guo (noni fruit) 30 g, You dun cao (Sabah snake grass) 30 g, Xiang lin tou (pandan leaves) 60 g. Boil with water and take orally. (Source: Hulu.com, Section of Experienced Formulae) * See Possible Toxicity and Cautions.

Diarrhea (Indonesia folk use): fresh herb one handful, water five cups decoct to three cups; divide into three doses and take.
Contraindications:
Caution on Noni fruit:
The Panel on Dietetic Products, Nutrition and Allergies of European Food Safety Authority concludes that “Morinda citrifolia (Noni) fruit puree and concentrate as novel food ingredients” under the specified conditions are considered safe for the general population. However the Panel considers that the increasing number of case reports might indicate that some individuals have a particular sensitivity for hepatotoxic effects to noni fruit products.

Noni fruit (and its products) are listed by the U.S. State Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as toxic items. There are reports that:
(1) those with renal dysfunction had higher chance for renal damage.
(2) more cases of acute hepatitis have been reported after consumption of noni products.

Maladies Treated: liver and spleen disharmony or cold constraint in the middle burner causing chest, flank, and epigastric distention and pain
coldness in chest and stomach resulting in bulging and pain in the stomach area
lumbar pain due to insufficient kidney yang
achy loin due to lack of circulation
hemangioma; the content of the abdomen of jiu xiang chong applied externally 3–4 times daily for several days
aneurysm; the content of the abdomen of jiu xiang chong applied externally 3–4 times daily for several days
chronic asthmatic bronchitis; jiu xiang chong baked to brown, powdered, mixed with chicken egg and pan-fried with sesame oil for oral intake
pain in stomach and intestines; jiu xiang chong combined with guang mu xiang to make an analgesic preparation
gallbladder colic; jiu xiang chong combined with guang mu xiang to make an analgesic preparation
ulcerative chronic colitis; decoction based on jiu xiang chong with bu gu zhi, wu wei zi, bai zhu, san qi, rou dou kou; total effective rate 87%
Medical Function: Warms the kidney and strengthens yang; corrects kidney yang deficient (溫腎壯陽)
Strong inhibiting effect on Staphylococcus aureus, Salmonella typhi, Bacillus paratyphosus, Shigella dysenteriae
Dosage: For decoction: 3–9 g. In powder form: 1.5–3 g.
Samples of Formulae: For chest pain: Jiu Xiang Chong (Aspongopus) 90 g, baked Quan Xie (Scorpion) 60 g. Grind into powder. Mix with refined honey and form pills of 3 g each. Take orally half a pill each time, twice a day. Source: Jilin Chinese Herb.
Contraindications: According to Ben Cao Cong Xin: not suitable for decoction because its slippery characteristic may increase bowel movements. Use with care in case of yinxu with fire (陰虚火旺慎服).
Research:
Clinical studies:
Hemangioma or aneurysm: use the content of the abdomen of live jiu xiang chong to smear on the hemangioma, 3–4 times daily; consecutive use for a few days can cure. (Jiangxu Traditional Chinese Medicine, 1996, 6: 24)

Chronic asthmatic bronchitis: bake jiu xiang chong till brown and grind into powder; mix with chicken egg, then pan-fry with sesame oil for eating. Treated 21 cases; total effective rate 100%. (Henan School of Traditional Chinese Medicine Journal, 1979, 4: 66)

Pain in stomach and intestines, or in gall bladder area: use jiu xiang chong with guang mu xiang to make an analgesic preparation; showed good effect for arresting pain. (Hunan School of Traditional Chinese Medicine Journal, 1990, 3: 157)

Ulcerated chronic colitis: use a decoction with jiu xiang chong as the main ingredient, adding bu gu zhi, wu wei zi, bai zhu, san qi, rou dou kou; total effective rate 87%. (Shaanxi Traditional Chinese Medicine, 1999, 4: 168)

There are reports of using a jiu xiang chong compound to treat geriatric atrophic gastritis (type A gastritis).
Chemical Ingredients: Jiu xiang chong oil: contains stearic acid, palmitic acid, oleic acid
The foul odor is attributed to aldehyde or ketone; the English text mentions flavonoid as a possible source of the odor

Name: tian hu sui
Botanical: Hydrocotyle sibthorpioides Lam. Var. batrachium (Hance) Hand.-Mazz.ex Shan
Other: jin qian cao (in Jiangxi) 金錢草[江西]
man tian xing (Sichuan) 滿天星[四川]
pu di jin (in Guangdong, Hunan) 鋪地錦[廣東、湖南]
pen shang yuan qian 盆上芫茜
pan shang yuan qian 盤上芫茜
xi ye qian miao kou 細葉錢苗口
luo di jin qian 落地金錢
guo lu wu gong 過路蜈蚣草
yu zha zi cao 魚察子草

pen shang yuan sui 盆上芫荽
xiao ye jin qian cao 小葉金錢草
xiao ye po tong qian 小葉破銅錢

Maladies Treated: 痈疽疔疮 (ulcer boils/carbuncles and boils)
Medical Function: Clears heat and toxin (清熱解毒)
Dosage:
Internal (oral): Decoction 9–10 g; or smash and make juice.
External application: Smash and apply; or stuff into nostrils; or smash and make juice for ear drops.
Research:
Anti pathogenic microorganism effect: 1:1 tian hu sui decoction, in vitro tests, showed strong inhibiting effect against Staphylococcus aureus. It also showed various degrees of inhibition of Proteus, Shigella, and Salmonella typhi.

Result of plague model test: rat-mode inhibition of 54%. For antimalarial screening using the whole plant of tian hu sui at 100 g/kg, the inhibition rate was 54%.

Oral coumarin 250 mg/kg produced a significantly hypoglycemic effect in normal diabetic rats.
Chemical Ingredients: Whole plant: lignan – sesamin (levorotatory; 左旋芝麻素)
References: [1] Zhong Hua Ben Cao 中華本草

Name: wu zhu yu
吳 茱 萸
Biological: Evodia rutaecarpa (Juss.) Benth. var. officinalis (Dode) Huang

Maladies Treated: excess acid of stomach/acid regurgitation (吞酸)
epigastric pain/pain in solar plexus (胃脘痛)
cold-damp swelling/beriberi-like leg condition (寒濕腳氣)
jueyin headache; headaches caused by vasomotor (vasoneurotic) dysfunction (厥陰頭痛/血管神經性頭痛)
Medical Function: warms the middle, lower qi (溫中下氣)
dispels cold of the Liver and Stomach; warms and scatters cold of the Liver and Stomach (溫散肝胃之寒)
leads fire downward (降火下行/Lead fire downward)

relaxes blood vessels by promoting excitement of the vascular endothelium, clearing the pathway of calcium ion, and releasing nitric oxide; inhibits platelet aggregation; inhibits formation of platelet thrombi and fibrin thrombi
analgesic effect; raises body temperature; in large amounts excites the central nervous system and causes visual impairment and illusions
Dosage: 3 to 9 g. Use with gan cao to reduce side effects.
Samples of Formulae: For headaches caused by vasomotor dysfunction (jueyin headache): Name of formula: Wu Zhu Yu Tang. Composition: Wu Zhu Yu (Evodia fruit) 1 part, Ren Shen (Ginseng root) 1 part, Da Zao (Jujube fruit) 1 part, Sheng Jiang (Fresh ginger) 1 part.
Contraindications:
Not suitable for shi zheng (strong/excess pattern), yinxu (yin deficient) with exuberant fire (陰虛火旺), and high fire body type.
Yin-deficiency fire exuberance symptom pattern: persistent strong penile erection (陰莖強硬不倒), spontaneous seminal discharge (精液自流), dizziness with fatigue of spirit (頭暈神疲), insomnia with many dreams (失眠多夢), soreness and weakness of the lumbar and knees (腰膝酸軟), vexing heat in the five centers (五心煩熱), dry mouth with night sweating (口乾盜汗), red tongue with little coating (舌紅少苔), thin rapid pulse (脈細數).
Research:
"Antidementic Drug Discovery from Oriental Herb Medicine: Dehydroevodiamine.HCl (DHED) extracted from Evodia Rutaecarpa Bentham prevents Impairment of Learning and Memory and Neuronal loss" – Cheol Hyoung Park (Korea).
Feeding the decoction to dogs showed that it lowered the blood pressure, but when combined with gan cao the effect disappeared. The lowering of blood pressure is the result of the expansion of the peripheral blood vessels and is caused by the secretion of histamine.
The decoction affected the activities of the small intestine of rabbits. Higher concentration inhibited the activities and lower concentration enhanced the activities.
Chemical Ingredients: rutaevine acetate 吳茱萸苦素乙酯 [5]
12 alpha-hydroxyevodol 12 a-羥基吳茱萸內酯醇 [6]
